bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, July 19, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks assistance in writing letters to get information on the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, July 19, 1940
div1.p:
As I think I told you, I had another paper to finish before starting the
yellow fever story. I will finish this within the week and will at once start on
the yellow fever job. I shall send to you a preliminary copy to show you what it
is all about and will ask your help in writing a half-dozen different individuals.
As you know, the Cubans are given to doing things “manana,” and three or four well
placed letters from you will help matters tremendously. Also I want to write a
couple letters--one to Mr. Pew in Pennsylvania, and one to a couple of others who
have been helping me. One of the men, who has some vital information concerning the
fact that Lazear got deliberate and not accidental yellow fever, is always out on me
for personal reasons, and I think a letter from you will be helpful. I shall explain
this all in a few days.

I do not know what possible connection Doctor Barker of Hopkins would have
had with Lazear that would interest us. He, of course, has been at Hopkins for a
long time and may have been a student or instructor or something when Lazear was
around there; but after Lazear got into yellow fever work, Barker had no connection
with him I am sure, and all that he knows is probably second-hand. I am sure that
Barker was never in Havana, and, of course, Lazear was there from the time of this
work until his death, so Barker would have no association with him. Reed was quite
a friend of Welch while he was at Hopkins, and I believe there is a certain amount
of “Reediana” at Hopkins. I intend to find out about this, but I am not anticipating
much help from Barker.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison
President of Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
